image.altText: Protest rally

items.synopsis: Upper house MPs spent all night debating the laws, which will significantly increase potential penalties for people who engage in disruptive protests.

title.children: Protest law changes pass SA parliament after marathon all-night debate

image.altText: An older man with greying light hair and glasses wearing a suit and tie stands in front of a blue Reserve Bank of Australia wall

items.synopsis: RBA boss Philip Lowe is facing a Senate estimates hearing before inflation figures are released, Tesla boss Elon Musk meets China's foreign minister in Beijing, and US investors remain cautious over the debt ceiling bill. Follow live.

title.children: RBA governor Philip Lowe faces Senate estimates grilling on interest rates, inflation

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: All sectors are now in the red on the ASX 200 index. Uranium miner Paladin Energy (+3.7 per cent) is higher after telling the market it is not aware of any legislative changes in Namibia that would affect the ownership of its Langer Heinrich mine in the country. Its shares plunged by one fifth yesterday after Namibia's mining minister said the country is considering taking minority stakes in mining and petroleum producers. Paladin says it has regular ongoing dialogue with all relevant Namibian government ministries. Coal miners Whitehaven Coal and New Hope are among the big losers on the ASX 200 index. The Bank of Queensland is also in the red after signing enforceable undertakings with Austrac and APRA. Here are the top movers on the ASX 200 index.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Paladin Energy not aware of Namibia plans to take stakes in miners

children.content: All sectors are now in the red on the ASX 200 index.

Uranium miner Paladin Energy (+3.7 per cent) is higher after telling the market it is not aware of any legislative changes in Namibia that would affect the ownership of its Langer Heinrich mine in the country.
Its shares plunged by one fifth yesterday after Namibia's mining minister said the country is considering taking minority stakes in mining and petroleum producers.
Paladin says it has regular ongoing dialogue with all relevant Namibian government ministries.
Coal miners Whitehaven Coal and New Hope are among the big losers on the ASX 200 index.
The Bank of Queensland is also in the red after signing enforceable undertakings with Austrac and APRA.
Here are the top movers on the ASX 200 index.

props.alt: Table showing best and worst performers on the ASX 200

children.content: ASX top movers
(Refinitiv)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Senator Nick McKim is now asking questions about rents and housing prices. He asks Philip Lowe whether high interest rates are having an impact on low demand for new houses and higher rents. McKim asks whether there is a "hole in the bucket" because "higher rents lead to higher inflation which lead to higher interest rates". McKim puts to Lowe that it is a "vicious cycle". "The cycle doesn't work like that," Lowe replies. "The solution isn't lower interest rates. "The solution is supply, supply, supply." Lowe delivers his solution response while tapping the desk with his open palm to hone his point.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Aren't higher interest rates leading to higher rents, which is fuelling inflation?

children.content: Senator Nick McKim is now asking questions about rents and housing prices.
He asks Philip Lowe whether high interest rates are having an impact on low demand for new houses and higher rents.
McKim asks whether there is a "hole in the bucket" because "higher rents lead to higher inflation which lead to higher interest rates".
McKim puts to Lowe that it is a "vicious cycle".
"The cycle doesn't work like that," Lowe replies.
"The solution isn't lower interest rates.
"The solution is supply, supply, supply."
Lowe delivers his solution response while tapping the desk with his open palm to hone his point.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Senator Dean Smith is asking the questions now, and has Philip Lowe about rents. "Rents is the single largest component of the CPI," Lowe says "We are expecting growth in rents to be around 10% ... it's very tough. "Some people are experiencing bigger increases than that. "The bigger issue here is supply and demand. the vacancy rates are very low." Lowe points to having visited Perth earlier this month for the most recent RBA board meeting, and said the city is experiencing its lowest rental vacancy rate on record. He says there are few things behind higher rental prices: The average number of people living in households declined as people wanted more space and worked from home, which affected demand There has been a big increase in population, with the population increasing by 2% this year. "Are there 2% more houses? No," Lowe says. "We've got a lot of people coming into the country, people wanting to live alone or move out of home. "The way that this ends up fixing itself is unfortunately through higher housing prices and higher rents. "We need more people on average to live in each dwelling, and higher prices do that." Senator Smith then paraphrases a hearing involving Treasury officials yesterday, who suggests that the end of high rent prices may be coming. Lowe admits he did not follow the Treasury's comments yesterday, but says that is not the expectation of the RBA, and expects a further increase in rent prices because markets are so tight and population growth is so strong. "That is ominous," Senator Smith replies.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: No relief from rising rent prices any time soon, Lowe says

children.content: Senator Dean Smith is asking the questions now, and has Philip Lowe about rents.
"Rents is the single largest component of the CPI," Lowe says
"We are expecting growth in rents to be around 10% ... it's very tough.
"Some people are experiencing bigger increases than that.
"The bigger issue here is supply and demand. the vacancy rates are very low."
Lowe points to having visited Perth earlier this month for the most recent RBA board meeting, and said the city is experiencing its lowest rental vacancy rate on record.
He says there are few things behind higher rental prices:
The average number of people living in households declined as people wanted more space and worked from home, which affected demand
There has been a big increase in population, with the population increasing by 2% this year.
"Are there 2% more houses? No," Lowe says.
"We've got a lot of people coming into the country, people wanting to live alone or move out of home.
"The way that this ends up fixing itself is unfortunately through higher housing prices and higher rents.
"We need more people on average to live in each dwelling, and higher prices do that."
Senator Smith then paraphrases a hearing involving Treasury officials yesterday, who suggests that the end of high rent prices may be coming.

Lowe admits he did not follow the Treasury's comments yesterday, but says that is not the expectation of the RBA, and expects a further increase in rent prices because markets are so tight and population growth is so strong.
"That is ominous," Senator Smith replies.

image.altText: a group of male students wearing backpacks walk through a uni campus away from the camera. their faces can't be seen

items.synopsis: For the past decade, student debts have increased by about 2 per cent a year on average, but tomorrow they will rise by a massive 7.1 per cent. The consequences of increased debt will affect graduates for decades.

title.children: Indexation of student debts to have lifelong impacts on Australians' borrowing capacity

image.altText: An elderly lady holds up two faded photos of a small, smiling boy

items.synopsis: It's been almost 50 years since Jimmy Taylor vanished from outside a shop in his home town. Now a new suspect and a $1 million reward have sparked hopes the mystery may be solved.

title.children: Jimmy Taylor was 12 when he vanished. Now there's a new suspect and a $1 million reward

image.altText: Antarctica hits new low sea ice extent

items.synopsis: Antarctica's sea ice is now reforming as the continent moves deeper into the austral winter, but it's currently the smallest it has ever been for this time of year on record. This blip in the Antarctic pulse is the latest in a string of record lows that is being watched carefully by scientists.

title.children: A stutter in Earth's icy heartbeat has 'gravely concerned' scientists searching for answers

image.altText: Graphic showing the merging of a human head and electronic circuits

items.synopsis: Top artificial intelligence executives join experts and professors in raising the "risk of extinction from AI", urging politicians to equate it with risks posed by pandemics and nuclear war.

title.children: Tech world warns risk of extinction from AI should be a global priority

image.altText: Former Hawthorn senior management Chris Fagan, Alastair Clarkson and Jason Burt.

items.synopsis: An independent panel investigating allegations of racism at the Hawthorn Football Club concludes, making no findings against former senior coaches and managers.

title.children: AFL shuts down Hawthorn racism review as First Nations players seek to 'resolve all differences'

image.altText: A worker abseils against a building to inspect drone damage.

items.synopsis: Russian President Vladimir Putin says the biggest-ever drone strike on Moscow targeted civilians, accusing Ukraine of an attack that would warrant a "severe" response.

title.children: Russia warns Ukraine of harsh response after 'terrorist' drone strike on Moscow

image.altText: Ice on a path with trees

items.synopsis: More than 100 Australian weather stations have just registered their coldest May minimum temperatures on record. And the cold snap had Sydney experiencing some of its iciest May nights in 66 years.

title.children: Australia shivers through one of its coldest Mays

image.altText: NIBLITT OUTSIDE HOUSE

items.synopsis: Two years after signing a $430,000 fixed price contract, boilermaker David Niblitt can no longer afford to finish the home that he and his wife had hoped they'd be living in by now.

title.children: David's half-built house is an 'absolute nightmare' and might send him bankrupt

image.altText: Linda Matthews holds a photo of her and her late husband

items.synopsis: When Brad Liefvoort died of a drug overdose, his wife didn't know he had been prescribed with thousands of highly addictive tablets from several GPs. His death has sparked a regulatory overhaul.

title.children: Brad was prescribed 'masses' of highly addictive drugs. His widow is demanding to know why

image.altText: A composite of three images

items.synopsis: With almost half of Australians having a parent born overseas, multicultural Australians' vote in the Voice referendum could prove significant. It's a cohort both the Yes and No campaigns are trying to court with community forums.

title.children: 'We can no longer be ignored': Why the Yes and No campaigns are courting multicultural votes ahead of the Voice referendum

image.altText: Kosovo tensions

items.synopsis: NATO will deploy more forces to northern Kosovo after 30 of its peacekeepers were injured in clashes with ethnic Serb protesters.

title.children: NATO to send 700 more troops to Kosovo to help quell violent protests

image.altText: A woman with a black blazer holders a book while standing in a garden.

items.synopsis: South Korea hoped that a 69-hour working week would encourage more women to have children and solve the country's ageing population problem, but women say the real barrier is embedded in the culture.

title.children: South Korea wants women to have more babies, but their latest idea outraged millennials and Gen Z

image.altText: Close up of blonde haired woman in dressed in black.

items.synopsis: The 39-year-old startup founder could spend more than 11 years inside a prison camp in Texas for defrauding investors in a hoax that became a parable about greed and hubris in Silicon Valley.

title.children: Elizabeth Holmes begins 11-year sentence for Theranos blood-testing hoax

image.altText: A street photograph of protesters carrying signs demanding an end to the Franklin dam plans.

items.synopsis: Activists involved in the protest that saved the Franklin River say the environmental win would not have been possible under today's anti-protest laws.

title.children: Their fight made history, but these environmental activists say their tactics wouldn't work today

image.altText: A man and woman sit a bench, looking at paper bills, with a calculator and laptop next to them

items.synopsis: Economists are divided on how well households will weather the storm of rent rises, soaring home loan rates and rising prices, just as Australians are divided in how much financial pressure they're under.

title.children: 'I don't think that's sustainable for the economy': How the RBA might drag Australia into recession

image.altText: Artist impression of a pterosaur flying over a beach

items.synopsis: Fossils dated to 107 million years old have been confirmed as the oldest evidence in Australia of the prehistoric flying reptile that some liken to the mythical dragon.

title.children: Fossils of prehistoric flying reptile found on Victorian coast are the oldest remains ever uncovered in Australia

image.altText: A swarovski bag full of cash and coupons, a pair of Air Jordans, a watch, a bottle of perfume and an apple.

items.synopsis: An ABC examination of the gifts handed to teachers in the past 18 months has found their receipt apparently breaches the enforceable regulation under the Queensland Public Sector Act.

title.children: Queensland teachers have been gifted robot vacuums, Air Jordans and concert tickets. Some are asking if it's too much

image.altText: The top of a police car with the word 'Police' on it. Some city buildings are in the background

items.synopsis: SA Police say they found the man on King William Street and told him to drop the knife, but he refused to comply.

title.children: Knife-wielding man tasered and arrested by police in Adelaide's CBD

image.altText: A young protester holds a placard bearing the words "born to protest".

items.synopsis: Hundreds of demonstrators gather below South Australian parliament's upper house to voice opposition to changes to the state's protest laws.

title.children: SA protest law change slammed by MP as the 'worst move ever' by a Labor premier

image.altText: Tony Sharley drives a small boat down the river with cliffs in the background

items.synopsis: Two months after Murray floodwaters receded along the river's South Australian reaches, nature is thriving in their wake — and that's music to the ears of conservationists in the region.

title.children: River regions given a new lease of life as floodwaters rejuvenate parched landscapes

image.altText: Four men in handcuffs stand with sheriff's officers outside a yellow brick building

items.synopsis: Four men accused of murdering Ridleyton man Victor Codea have been found guilty of the lesser charge of manslaughter in Adelaide's Supreme Court.

title.children: Four men accused of murdering Victor Codea at Adelaide High School found guilty of manslaughter

image.altText: A man climbing up from train tracks as a train approaches

items.synopsis: Footage of pedestrians engaging in risky behaviour around trains has been released by the state government in a bid to reduce the number of collisions.

title.children: 'Harrowing' footage shows near misses between pedestrians and trains across Adelaide

image.altText: A stern man in a suit walks outside court as a video photographer follows him

items.synopsis: Chris Dawson's former student has given evidence against the 74-year-old convicted murderer, who is facing one count of carnal knowledge, in the NSW District Court.

title.children: Chris Dawson treated student like his 'property' and 'groomed' her, court told

image.altText: A man in a dark navy suit and pink tie speaks in parliament, with an Indigenous female minister sitting behind, watching on

items.synopsis: The new Australian Centre for Evaluation will be tasked with examining whether government programs work — before they are rolled out. Imagine how much good it could do if it's allowed to, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: Will Albanese live up to his own promises to end pork-barrelling? There is a sliver of hope

image.altText: Chris Jordan stares intently while answering a question at Senate Estimates. His brow is furrowed.

items.synopsis: The Australian Taxation Office raised concerns about a confidentiality breach at PwC to Australian Federal Police in March 2018, but a lack of detail meant no investigation was launched.

title.children: Lack of detail stopped federal police initially investigating PwC breach

image.altText: A man in a black suit and tie speaks at a press conference.

items.synopsis: WA Deputy Premier Roger Cook will be the state’s next premier, after Health Minister Amber-Jade Sanderson confirms she has withdrawn from the leadership contest.

title.children: Roger Cook to become WA's new premier after all other contenders pull out of race

image.altText: Major General Angus Campbell accepts a salute during the transition parade at Al Minhad Airbase, United Arab Emirates.

items.synopsis: The Australian Defence Force chief is grilled in parliament over moves to revoke military honours from some soldiers who served in Afghanistan, with one senator suggesting General Angus Campbell should "surrender" his own medal.

title.children: One Nation senator challenges ADF chief to 'surrender' Afghanistan medal

image.altText: A birds eye view of brown flood water, with a line of shack roofs alongside a line of trees

items.synopsis: Flood-affected property owners are concerned their council rates will rise in line with the booming property market despite some of their properties being deemed uninhabitable.

title.children: Flooded property owners worry about rate rises linked to valuer-general's valuations
